title: Mum and two daughters were 'smiling and happy' before being 'murdered' by dad
text:

A mum and her two young daughters were 'smiling and happy' before they were murdered by their father, the Old Bailey heard today.

Mohammed Abdul Shakur, 46, is accused of killing wife Juli Begum, 26, along with children Anika, five, and Thanha, six, at their home in east London, on New Year's Day in 2007.

The chef told a travel agent he was 'in a hurry' to visit his ill mother and fled to Bangladesh a few days later, the murder trial heard.

Today evidence was heard from mum-of-four Mary Banweyana, who was Ms Begum's neighbour in East Ham.

(Image: NICHOLAS RAZZELL)

In a witness statement Ms Banweyana said: "Juli had a husband. He did not live at home, I believe. She said her husband was working as a chef in a restaurant or in McDonald's.

"I saw Juli every day with her children, taking them to school or picking them up. We would talk to each other, and say hello and ask how are the girls.

"She came to my house about twice. She would come with her girls and they would play with my children. She and her children were always smiling and happy.

"Juli would stop and talk to me but Shakur never did. Whenever I saw him I would never say hello or anything. He never spoke to me.

"The last time I saw Juli's children was when they finished school for the Christmas holidays. The children seemed fine and very happy.

"The last time I saw Juli was December 28. I was outside my house washing my husband's car. We said hello to each other.

"I never saw any visitors to Juli's house."

Ms Banweyana didn't know anything was wrong until she saw Ms Begum's sister Sheli checking on her.

Sheli called the police after her sister didn't answer her door.

The bodies of Ms Begum and her children were then found with sheets draped over them.

Jurors heard Shakur had had sex with his wife one last time before suffocating her, then strangling Anika with a sock and beating Thanha to death.

Two days later, at about one o'clock on January 3, Shakur went to a travel agent to purchase a one-way ticket to Bangladesh.

Witness Mohammed Choudry, who worked at KMC Travel Agency in London at the time, said: "He said his mother was unwell so he was in a hurry.

"It wasn't unusual. We would see people, especially Bangladeshis, purchasing one-way tickets."

There were no flights available that evening so Shakur booked an air India flight, the cheapest one available, for 9pm the next day. He paid £340, the court heard.

Police later managed to pinpoint Shakur's phone to the vicinity of Heathrow Airport on January 4.

Shakur, formerly of Whitechapel, denies three counts of murder.

The trial continues.
description: Mohammed Abdul Shakur, 46, is on trial over the deaths of wife Juli Begum, 26, and children Anika, five, and Thanha, six
